awd_titl_txt: Advanced Industrial Instrumentation Control Technician Education
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will contribute to development of a skilled technical workforce by improving an Industrial Instrumentation degree program.  The improved curriculum will include training in advanced automation control and troubleshooting skills in chemical manufacturing control systems. The degree will emphasize the Industrial Internet of Things (IIoT) operational model, Industry 4.0 troubleshooting methods, and modern Human Machine Interface. The river region of southern Louisiana has a growing demand for Industrial Instrumentation Control Technicians with experience in advanced automation control and troubleshooting skills. These technicians are vital to the daily operations of petro-chemical plants and are responsible for troubleshooting, tuning, and programming automation components. As a result, there is an ongoing need to advance the skills of industrial instrumentation control technicians in IIoT operations and in Industry 4.0 methods. The degree will also emphasize 21st century technical skills, such as critical thinking and information literacy, to produce a well-educated, productive technical workforce for this diverse, rural region. 

The project will deconstruct and redesign an existing Industrial Instrumentation degree program by using the Business and Industry Leadership Team (BILT) evaluation plan. Content will be developed by working closely with industry partners to develop an Introduction to IIoT course and an Industry 4.0 capstone course. In addition, selected modules in the new courses will be incorporated into the Process Technology degree coursework. This project has three targeted outcomes: 1) Researching intrinsically safe portable Human Machine Interface devices that communicate equipment and personnel GPS positioning, process systems automation control, and industrial plant process health; 2) Designing coursework to address the interface of the IIoT – Operational Technology/Information Technology communications requirements and Industry 4.0 troubleshooting skills; and 3) Implementing core STEM skill modules that address the academic needs of a diverse, rural student population. The courses will immerse students in an integrated approach to plant operations and troubleshooting. These courses will be developed out of an acknowledged need in the business community for technicians who work in cross-disciplinary teams in which instrumentation technicians and process technology workers are able to envision plant controls as a system. This project is funded by the Advanced Technological Education program that focuses on the education of technicians for the advanced-technology fields that drive the nation's economy.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The outcomes for the “Advanced Industrial Instrumentation Control Technician Training” Project at River Parishes Community College (RPCC) were as follows:

● Research intrinsically safe portable human machine interface (HMI) devices, which communicate equipment and personnel GPS positioning, process systems automation control, and industrial plant process health.

● Design curriculum coursework that addressed the interface of the IIoT – OT/IT communications requirements and Industry 4.0 troubleshooting skills identified by our regional petro-chemical industrial industry partners; and

● Integrate core STEM modules to address the academic needs of a diverse, rural student population.

Research Human Machine Interface (HMI) Devices

Industrial grade Human Machine Interface (HMI) devices are considered tools for production technicians in the Industry 4.0 process environment. These devices need to be intrinsically safe because of the explosive potential in the petro-chemical processing environment. RPCC worked with its local business and industry partners to acquire and test numerous brands and models of HMI devices to ensure their capabilities and usability. RPCC utilized the PET Plant located at the community college as a controlled test environment, to put each HMI safely and effectively through its paces. The criteria used included safety in industrial environments, tactile handling and data input, and wireless interface into IIoT and communications networks (Ealahan, 2018). Students from the Instrumentation (I&E) Program and industry plant technicians participated in this research as the HMI industry evolves.

After evaluating multiple HMI devices, RPCC purchased a PM-522 Rugged Tablet PC and a Durabook U11i Rugged Tablet. In addition, two TREX communicators were purchased to support the I&E courses. This enabled the students to work with the latest technology in instrument interface devices when calibrating, maintaining the health of field instrumentation and providing a platform for record keeping for each loop in the process environment. Also, RPCC worked with a local vendor, John H. Carter, to complete the WI-FI WI-HART PET Project Addition, thus allowing for wireless interface into IIoT and communications with the PET Plant. This portion of the project was critical to the next phase of the project: design the coursework competencies to define the interface of the IIoT transmission technologies.

Program Improvement Utilizing the Creation of Cross-Curricular Courses for Petro-Chemical Students

Utilizing models of quality curriculum review strategies, such as the Electronics Technicians Association International (ETA) credentials (Poelma & Cleveland, 2019) and “Enhancing the Instrumentation and Control Technician Program Instrumentation Acquisition” (Zube & Land, 2018), a complete industry-based partnership review of RPCC's Instrumentation degree program was conducted. This review led to the elimination of competencies that were obsolete and the restructuring of the degree program to include new IIoT and Industry 4.0 courses. During this reorganization, Instrumentation lecture and Instrumentation Lab course credit hours were identified for this Industry 4.0 content.

The I&E courses that were part of this project was adapted from the project-based learning model developed by the Buck Institute of Education, as well as industry-based scenarios from SC ATE, in order to immerse RPCC students in an ecosystem approach to plant operations and troubleshooting. The lecture course covered many of the core concepts of scalable, secure technologies and services in the Industrial Internet of Things (IIoT) that are relevant to the process industry. The second course addressed Industry 4.0 technologies and was a project-based capstone experience for a cohort of students, selected from RPCC’s instrumentation and process technology programs. The projects designed for the advanced capstone course involved real-world integration of IIoT concepts and Industry 4.0 technologies and utilized the RPCC PET Plant as the functional lab to conduct the lab coursework. Another key feature of these 2 courses was the integration core STEM modules to address the academic needs of a diverse, rural students.

 Integrating STEM Modules Addressing the Academic Needs of Diverse, Rural Students

This project used strategies outlined in the five Modules of the National Alliance of Partnerships in Equity (NAPE) STEM Equity Pipeline Project, to identify gaps in the participation of underrepresented populations in the Industrial Instrumentation (I&E) and Process Technology (PTEC) degree programs. A thorough study of enrollment data and trends revealed that females were not well-represented in RPCC's Instrumentation Program. Project funds were utilized to secure customized recruiting materials that targeted females. The I&E Program has seen a 10% increase in the participation of females.

This project also worked to bridge the skills gap of many I&E students by providing STEM-focused learning modules to complement their coursework. STEM modules on fundamentals such as Basic Math Topics, Circuits, Physics Fundamentals, and Electrical Safety were created using resources from the PhET Interactive Simulations project at the University of Colorado Boulder, Skills Commons, Wisc-Online created by Wisconsin’s Technical Colleges, MERLOT, and 180 Skills. These STEM modules, which currently reside in our Canvas LMS, are portable and offer an effective method to bolster STEM capabilities while presenting a cost-savings to students since they are free.
